abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Power Transmission Project of
            Yugoslavia has successfully achieved its major objective of
            completing the second phase of the program. Despite periodic
            strained situations between the Bank and the Union of
            Yugoslav Electric Power Industry (JUGEL), particularly in
            the earlier years of the Project, the project has resulted
            in the Bank having a much clearer understanding of the
            philosophy and constraints of the Yugoslav social economic
            system and organization as it applies to the electricity
            power sector. The main lessons to be learned from the
            Project are: (a) that the constraints of available internal
            finance, foreign exchange and absorptive capacity of the
            sector and a sharp slowing of the economy would, in a
            project such as this, significantly reduce load growth and
            necessitate drastic curtailment of expansion programs; (b)
            that successful administration of loans to the power sector
            of Yugoslavia is constrained because of the fragmented
            nature of the Sector; and (c) that a real commitment on the
            part of the borrowers and the Government to the objectives
            of the Project is critical for its success, as demonstrated
            by the lack of beneficial results from the work of the
            financial management consultants.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is the second phase of a
            380-kV power transmission network. The project comprises the
            construction of about 1,000 km of single circuit
            transmission lines, 16 new substations and the extension of
            8 existing substations with a total transformer capacity of
            about 10,000 MVA, 3 switching stations, and 9 dispatch
            centers (1 federal, 6 republican, and Kosovo). The project
            includes studies of management, tariffs, and system
            development. The 380-kV system coupled with adequate
            dispatch facilities is designed to allow for greater
            reliability, flexibility, and economy in supplying power
            throughout the country. The second phase (1977-82) of the
            380-kV system is an extension and refinement of the basic
            power grid established under the first phase or first Power
            Transmission Project in 1972.
